div.div: Go to the official Node.js website: https://nodejs.org/en
Download the recommended LTS (Long Term Support) version. The installer will automatically install npm as well.
Download and install Node.js:
Open your terminal or command prompt.
Type:node -v npm -v
You should see the version numbers, confirming a successful installation.
Verify the installation:
Step 1: Install Node.js and npm
This is the most common method, allowing you to use the tsc command from any folder.
In your terminal, type:npm install -g typescript
Note: On Linux/macOS, you might need to use sudo before the command (e.g., sudo npm install -g typescript).
Install globally:
Type:tsc -v
You should see the TypeScript version.
Verify the installation:
Step 2: Install TypeScript
Create a new folder for your project:mkdir my-ts-project cd my-ts-project
Inside the my-ts-project folder, create a file named app.ts (the .ts extension is for TypeScript files).
Notice how we declared the types (e.g., name: string, : string for the return value, userName: string).
Create a TypeScript file:
Step 3: Set up Your Project
In your terminal, make sure you are inside the my-ts-project folder.
Type:tsc app.ts
This command will create a new file named app.js in the same folder. If you open it, you'll see the corresponding JavaScript code, without the type declarations.
Compile the file:
You should see the message "Hello, World! Welcome to TypeScript!" in the console.
Execute the JavaScript code:node app.js
Step 4: Compile TypeScript to JavaScript
Inside the my-ts-project folder, type:tsc --init
This command will create a tsconfig.json file with many commented-out options.
Create tsconfig.json:
"target": "es2016" (or newer): Specifies which version of JavaScript your code will be compiled to.
"outDir": "./dist": Specifies a folder where the compiled JavaScript files will be placed.
"rootDir": "./src": Specifies the folder where your original TypeScript files are located (if you want to organize them).
For starters, you can leave most settings as they are. Two important settings you might be interested in are:
If you define outDir, you'll just need to compile with tsc (without a file name), and all .ts files will be compiled into the dist folder.
Basic settings in tsconfig.json:
Step 5: Configure tsconfig.json (Optional but Recommended)
Highly recommended. It has excellent built-in support for TypeScript, providing auto-completion, real-time error checking, refactoring, and much more.
Download it from here: https://code.visualstudio.com/
With VS Code, you'll see type errors directly in your editor as you type, even before you try to compile the code.
Visual Studio Code (VS Code):
Step 6: Use an IDE (Very Important!)
TypeScript Quick Start Guide
